fields.description: As discussed in MAPREDUCE-5261, there's a possibility that a DNS outage could lead to an unhandled exception in the ResourceManager's AsyncDispatcher, and that ultimately would cause the RM to exit.  The RM should not exit during DNS hiccups.
fields.summary: ResourceManager can exit unexpectedly if DNS is unavailable

comments.body: I was preparing a patch for this, but I noticed that after the revert of the patch of MAPREDUCE-5261, the problem reported in MAPREDUCE-5261 still exists, i.e., TestRMContainerAllocator#testSimple throws the exception. I guess I am missing something since [~vinodkv] had reported that this problem is fixed by a change in core-site.xml.

[~maysamyabandeh] do you see this problem now? after reverting the patch only on trunk (YARN-571 has added the file)? have you added any core-site.xml file in your classpath? 

The issue reported here is still present but test case should not fail.
Thanks [~ojoshi]. The problem was that the classpath in eclipse was not properly set. I am getting back to generate a patch for this jira.

A preliminary patch is attached. Three points:
# With the new changes of YARN-571, I did not find a way to write a unit test that simulates a DNS error. I am temporarily changing the visibility of setTokenServiceUserIp to allow the test go thorough.
# The patch catches the IllegalArgumentException and verifies whether it is related to IP resolving. I guess a cleaner way is to directly throw the UnknownHostException at SecurityUtil.java
# The current patch simply logs the exception. I am wondering whether a more complicated reaction is desired, such as recirculating the event after a timeout. In general, we should determine which component is responsible of retrying a failed event.

The visibility of setTokenServiceUseIp does not need to change.  If you need to access it for tests, use SecurityUtilTestHelper.setTokenServiceUseIp.

I don't think handling this in AsyncDispatcher is the appropriate place for the very same reason you're wondering -- what is it going to do about it?  It has almost no recourse for handling the event properly since it's operating at such a high level relative to what generated the error.  It would be better to handle the unknown host exception in a more targeted manner.  Looking at the stack trace from MAPREDUCE-5261, createContainerToken or assignContainer would probably be better targets for a fix.  assignContainer already handles a null result from createContainerToken, maybe createContainerToken should return null when it cannot create a token?
That, and we should do a sweep of YARN RM (and NM too?) to see where else we depend on DNS..
Note that this had been fixed at one time by MAPREDUCE-4295, but was lost.

Thanks [~tgraves]. The changes of this patch is more or less the same of the changes applied at MAPREDUCE-4295. The updates were lost during the merge of an outdated patch in YARN-39. I am submitting the patch to get some reviews.

The patch does not apply the discussed change of throwing a more proper exception in the case of DNS failure, as it would result in widespread changes and I am not sure whether we want to go for it now.

Tx Maysam for taking this up!

Quickly looked at the patch, few comments:

Not exactly caused by your patch, but we need to fix the callers of the container-creation code too. Just returning null isn't enough unfortunately.
 - In LeafQueue, I think the containerToken creation and null check should move above the unReserve. In case of DNS issues, we don't want to just unreserve the resources and *not* allocate containers. Please do leave code comment saying it has to happen before making destructive changes.
 - Similarly in AppSchedulable.java, after  createContainer() at +237, we should check for null-container and return none resources.

I think the test is better placed in ResourceManager module. Please move it there to a new test-file. You can move MyResourceManager, MyFifoScheduler etc to ResourceManager and reuse them in MR.
The attached patch applied the comments of [~vinodkv]. The unit test is also moved to resourcemanager package close to the modules that are modified. Reviews are appreciated.

This same thing needs to be done for YARN-694 ( NMToken )
[~maysamyabandeh] are you working on a patch? Or else I will take over..this is critical and needs to be fixed.
[~ojoshi], but the patch was ready since June 14! Anyway, feel free to take over.
We want to cover NMTokens too in the similar fashion as a part of this ticket... if you want to work on that then you can continue... or else I will take over in the evening... Thanks..
Creating patch on top of YARN-957

I wanted to change that long ago, but the problem is the ripple effect of adding a checked exception to the signature.

I actually started to change this code at one time because there's no reason that the address should be resolved for every token.  I split the patch out of a larger change (and then lost it) but I made the nodeId store the {{InetSocketAddress}}.  I added {{getSocketAddr}} so it could be queried for {{setTokenService}} and other places that needlessly keep reconstructing an {{InetSocketAddress}}.

Addressing NMToken and ContainerToken issue here. I am now creating ContainerToken and NMToken together to make sure that we always have both created.
* first we will create ContainerToken
* then NMToken
if both succeed then only current container will be either assigned or will be reserved depending on the scheduler logic. However if any of them fails them we will discard the container and try again later. Added test cases for all 3 schedulers.

Also fixed YARN-1417 as a part of this. It is straight forward.

The patch isn't applying.

Can we separate YARN-1417 from this patch?
Just stumbled upon this. [~ojoshi] - should we revisit this and fix?
I'd like to take this over.

New patch:
- Move the creation of NMToken to the same place where container token is created.
- Catch the exception and return empty allocation for that container if either container token or NMToken creation fails because of DNS unavailable.
- Add a new field nmTokens in Allocation.java
- Change AMContainerAllocatedTransition to retry if the am container is not fetchable because token creation fails.

Tx for the update Jian. Few comments
 - Fix the findBugs warning
 - AplicationMasterService: Retain the {{!allocation.getContainers().isEmpty()}} check before setting NMTokens.
 - Add documentation for SchedulerApplicationAttempt.pullNewlyAllocatedContainersAndNMTokens()
 - RMAppAttemptContainerAllocatedEvent.getContainer() seems unused, remove it
 - NMTokenSecretManagerInRM:
    -- Put the log message in a debugEnabled check
    -- Improve the comment as to why you are not adding NMtoken when this is the AM container. It wasn't easy to understand, please make it more detailed
 - I think the code path for AM container retry is not tested. Please augment the test.
New patch fixed the comments and added a new unit test for testing AM container retry.

The patch looks much better. Hopefully the final set of comments: 
 - If there are DNS issues while allocating the AM container, there is a tight loop. May be resend the container-allocated event in a thread after 500ms or something? This should be okay? Do we invalidate any assumptions if we do this?
 - In the test testAMContainerAllocationWhenDNSUnavailable(), you should
    -- keep retrying till numRetries becomes, say, >5
    -- Also sleep for a second before every retry
    -- Within the loop and after it exits, validate the state of RMAppAttempt or the AM container itself. Right now, it is not clear what is getting validated in the test.

bq. May be resend the container-allocated event in a thread after 500ms
Agree, better than a tight loop.

Uploaded a new patch that fixed the comments.
New patch with minor more fix
